# Data

We usually use Panads for handling data that is organized in tables. Tables are two-dimensional. In other words, they have a length (number of rows) and a width (number of columns). Each row represents an observation and each of the values in a row represents some property describing the corresponding observation.

In the following table, we show some data which might stem from an online fitness platform. Each observation is a physical activity. In this example, each physical activity has an ID and is also described by the type of activity, duration, and the user who performed the activity.

```{python}
#| echo: false
#| label: tbl-chapter-1-example-table
#| tbl-cap: Example table
import pandas as pd
pd.DataFrame(
    {
        "Activity ID": [1, 25, 39, 101, "â€¦"],
        "User ID": [42, 22, 1, 42, "â€¦"],
        "Activity Type": ["run", "hike", "bike", "run", "â€¦"],
        "Duration in Minutes": [60, 210, 120, 45, "â€¦"]
    },
    index=[0, 1, 2, 3, "â€¦"]
)
```

Usually, datasets with only four records are not that interesting. The `â€¦` entries are there to indicate that more data exist, however, we don't show them in most of the cases to keep the tables concise.

```{python}
#| echo: false
#| tbl-cap: Example table with data on events
pd.DataFrame(
    {
        "User ID": [1, 22, 42, "â€¦"],
        "Name": ["Carl", "Barbara", "Aleks", "â€¦"],
        "E-mail": ["charlie@example.com", "barbara@example.com", "aleks@example.com", "â€¦"],

    index=[0, 1, 2, "â€¦"]
)
```

## Outlook

In the following few chapters, we'll start as simple as possible, focusing on a single row or a single column of a table. Once we have a firm grasp of working with individual rows and columns, moving to tables will feel like a natural extension. So, first, we will learn how to

- represent a row or column in Pandas,
- perform calculations on the elements of a row or column,
- get and set specific elements of a row or column, and
- filter a row or column using simple as well as compound conditions.
